prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tracing the active dense gas in the high-contrast region of the IRDC
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Here, we want to trace the active, more turbulent gas in the northern region of the filament, by using the combination of HCO+ / H13CO+. In parallel, we estimate the 100 GHz continuum emission on scales of around 4 arcsec to identify cores. These will be compared to the cores identified by us in the far-infrared using Herschel/PACS mapping as well as APEX/SABOCA 350 micron data (Ragan et al. 2013, A&A 559, A79).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This proposal asks for 3-mm observations using two different frequency tunings. This is guided by our desire to trace two complementary dense gas tracers in this band, N2H+ and HCO+. Unfortunately, both lines cannot be tuned simultaneously according to the OT. Hence, we decided to do the two lines subsequently in separate science goals, which in turn gives us the opportunity to include other important spectral lines (e.g., CH3CCH as a gas temperature tracer) and the 3mm continuum, respectively, into the USB. It is not possible to cover the whole region shown in Fig. 1 with ALMA. Also a large mosaic just covering the area spanning from the HMPO to the IRDC would exceed the number of allowed pointings. We hence have created two smaller disjunct mosaics, one covering the HMPO and the bump region, and one covering the actual IRDC. Since we want to cover both key lines (in Tuning A and Tuning B, respectively) in both mosaics, we have distributed our observations over four OT science goals. Lines in cold environments can be narrow and attain linewidth of <1 km/s, even in IRDCs. Since we also want to discern small velocity gradients in the gas, we opted for a resolution of ~0.2 km/s. For this science goal, we decided to devote the USB to measure the 3-mm continuum around 100 GHz. All other basebands are tuned to molecular lines. Our sensitivity assumptions are driven by the detectability of H13CO+. We have Mopra data for this (Vasyunina et al. 2011). The H13CO+ peak brightness temperature in the IRDC is 1.1 K which translates to 8.78 Jy. We want to recover line emission that is up to 7 times weaker in the outskirts of the mosaic. We now set the sensitivity goal to the expected flux in the worst-case scenario that all of this emission had a beam filling factor of 1 for Mopra. The area ratio of the Mopra beam (36") and the ALMA synthesized beam (4.3") gives then a sensitivity goal of 17.9 mJy for the 0.2 km/s velocity resolution. This results in 1.47 min per pointing. The antenna configuration is C34-1, i.e., the most compact setting that is still susceptible to extended emission. However, even this compact array gives us a spatial resolution of around 4"-4.5", which is a very good match to the resolution of MIPS24 and the best Herschel resolution (5"-6"). The shortest baseline is 15.1 m. Hence, there is an overlap with our Mopra single-dish mapping of the key lines (Mopra diameter 22 m), which can be used as zero-spacing component. For this science goal, we need times (including overheads) of 1.5 h for a total number of 33 pointings.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tackling the quiescent gas in the high-contrast region of the IRDC
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Here, we want to trace the quiescent gas in the norther region of the filament, by using N2H+. In parallel, we have tuned the CH3CCH(6-5) line series which is a gas temperature tracer. HNC(1-0) is another dense gas tracer, especially abundant in early phases of the star-formation process.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Herschel gave us a plethora of filamentary structures based on column density maps. For assessing the dynamics of star formation therein we need to investigate the gas motions. We conducted a Herschel study towards 45 high-mass star-forming clumps. A striking object is the filamentary IRDC 316.72+0.07, attaining high peak column densities (>10^23 cm^-2) and low dust temperatures (<14 K). The Herschel data show more chaotic column column density structures in parts of this IRDC. The ALMA observations are guided by our previous single-dish molecular line mapping. We plan to mosaic the IRDC with ALMA at 3 mm. We want to probe the quiescent gas with N2H+, and the more active turbulent gas with HCO+/H13CO+. Objectives: 1) Trace the distribution and kinematics of quiescent gas. Are there hints for coherent velocity structures, with gas gradually decoupling from the turbulent gas and proceeding with gravitational collapse? 2) Understanding the dynamics of the active dense gas. Is there infall of inter-clump material onto the dense filament on larger scales? The kinematics of the gas on scales of 4" will then be compared to numerical simulations of filament formation and converging flows.
